intro: Bupleurum baldense, commonly known as the bald mountain angelica, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbrella-like inflorescences, typical of the family. Bupleurum baldense thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies in high-altitude environments.
